'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''', and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from the ancient Greek words: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). The term appears to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>

'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''', and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from the ancient Greek words: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "love"). The term appears to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref> snow white's prince had necrophilia
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153â163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | year = 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = | journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153â163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
